importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the satellite launch announcement marks a significant milestone in Pakistan's space capabilities and national technological advancement.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Pakistan’s space programme activity in 2025, including the launch of three satellites, reflects a strategic push toward technological self-reliance and space-based applications.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major breakthrough in its space programme.
The H1 satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology enables detection of subtle chemical changes on Earth’s surface, useful for agriculture, water management, and disaster response.
SUPARCO, Pakistan’s space agency, reported the successful launch and described it as a pivotal step in national development and space capabilities.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The launch strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China, especially in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
The data from H1 is expected to improve agricultural productivity, climate resilience, and natural resource management.
Two previous satellites, EO-1 and KS-1, are already operational, indicating a broader trend of space programme growth in Pakistan.
It may take about two months to fully calibrate the H1 satellite before it becomes fully operational.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pakistan is the entity launching a new space technology, signifying its growing role in space science and technological self-reliance.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is responsible for the launch and management of Pakistan’s space missions, including this hyperspectral satellite.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite is central to the article as it represents a technological advancement in Earth observation and national development.

namedEntities.name: Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A space launch facility in China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The launch site in China indicates international collaboration and Pakistan's reliance on external infrastructure for space launches.

namedEntities.name: China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China is a key partner in Pakistan’s space programme, providing launch services and contributing to the strategic space partnership.

namedEntities.name: China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure development linking Xinjiang, China, with Pakistan’s Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite’s capability to monitor geohazards supports infrastructure safety and development within CPEC.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are fully operational and provide context for Pakistan’s broader growth in space capabilities.

namedEntities.name: Precision agriculture
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A method of farming using technology to optimize crop yields
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a key application area for the hyperspectral satellite data.

namedEntities.name: Environmental monitoring
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The tracking of environmental changes over time
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is one of the primary fields where hyperspectral satellite data will be used.

namedEntities.name: Disaster management
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The response to natural disasters such as floods or earthquakes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hyperspectral imaging can detect damage from disasters, enhancing early warning and response systems.

namedEntities.name: Water resources
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Natural resources critical for agriculture and urban use
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite will help monitor and manage water resources more efficiently.

namedEntities.name: Geohazard risks
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Natural risks such as landslides or earthquakes
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The satellite helps in identifying and mitigating geohazard risks for development projects.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre, marking a major milestone in its space programme. The satellite, capable of detecting subtle chemical changes on Earth’s surface, will support national efforts in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. This advancement strengthens Pakistan’s technological capacity and its strategic partnership with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC). While the H1 satellite is expected to be fully operational within about two months, two earlier satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already operational, showing a broader trend of growth in Pakistan’s space capabilities.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
